string-array.item: Normal: Standard chess rules with the classic goal of checkmating the opponents king.
Antichess: A playful variant where the goal is to lose all your pieces or get stalemated. Players must sacrifice pieces and avoid checkmate.
Berolina: Pawns move diagonally and capture straight ahead, flipping their standard rules.
Grasshopper: Introduces the "Grasshopper," a piece that moves like a queen but must jump over other pieces to move or capture.
Asean: Bishops move only one or two squares diagonally. The queen moves only one square diagonally.
Almost: The queen is replaced by a chancellor, a piece which combines the moves of the rook and the knight.
Atomar: Capturing a piece triggers an explosive chain reaction that removes surrounding pieces.
Breakthrough: Pawns only; the goal is to get one pawn to the opponentâ€™s back rank.
Cambodian: the queen moves one square diagonally, bishops move diagonally or one square forward, and the king has a knight-like jump on its first move.
Chaturanga: the game includes two new pieces - the "Elephant" (moves similar to a modern rook) and "Chariot" (moves like the rook).
Codrus: the objective is to have your king captured to win.
Coregal: Both the king and queen are royal; checkmate either to win, adding extra strategy. Players must protect both pieces.
Chigorin: Replaces both knights with bishops and the queen with a chancellor (combination of rook and knight).
Fischerandom: Pieces are shuffled randomly on the back rank, creating new openings and strategies.
